RFCloak: Randomizing the Readers Signal Random waveform: Must change as fast as any transition in the RFID signal has same bandwidth as RFID signal
Must be indistinguishable from white noise i.e. flat frequency profile samples taken from complex Gaussians
Theorem 1: Using RFCloaks random signal an eavesdropper will not be able to distinguish a 0 bit from a 1 bit which is no better than a random guess
Threat model: Single antenna eavesdropper using the optimal decoder
What if the attacker has multiantenna MIMO capability?

Theorem 2: Using RFCloaks channel randomization, a MIMO eavesdropper will not be able to distinguish a 0 bit from a 1 bit which is no better than a random guess
Threat model: Multiantenna MIMO eavesdropper using the optimal decoder.
Implemented RFCloak on USRP N210 software radios and combined it with a 1725 rpm motor and ADG904R RF switches.

Securing RFIDs against eavesdropping: [CHES07, RFIDSec11, CARDIS06, JRSC12, PerCom07]
Moving antennas: [SIGCOMM14, MOBICOM14, HOTNETS14, MOBICOM13, SIGCOM13, HotMobile12, ISJ14]
RFCloak is the first system that can protect deployed RFIDs against eavesdropping without any modification to the RFID
RFCloak is the first system that can hide the signal from MIMO attacker with many antennas even when the reader has no MIMO capability.
RFCloak provides a defense in depth solution.
